Issues.Title: Hook BinaryFormatter replacement in Resx / Clipboard
Issues.Body:
This uses the BinaryFormat support classes to handle common framework types before falling back to the BinaryFormatter.

There is some cleanup in the Resx code and simplification in DataObject by adding internal constant strings for known DataFormats.

Also move MultitargetUtil to the normal CriticalException handler.

Issues.Title: Bounds for PrintPreviewControl and its accessible object don't match
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-preview.5.23274.2

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it works in .NET 6.0/7.0. Regression form: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9136

### Issue description

Testapp: [testapp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11563155/testapp.zip)

.NET 8.0
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/f83342cb-8025-4354-9e3e-6c16ea8fd211)

.NET 7.0
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/b4e2145b-ff3f-49f0-884e-c324cfbe7ca5)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a WinForms .NET Core project.
2. Add a button and printPreviewControl control to form designer.
3. Double click button1 and type below code in function button1_Click.
```
AccessibleObject accessibleObject = printPreviewControl1.AccessibilityObject;
Rectangle rectangle1 = accessibleObject.Bounds;
Rectangle rectangle2 = printPreviewControl1.RectangleToScreen(printPreviewControl1.ClientRectangle);
```
4. Add a breakpoint at the end of the event, build and run the application.
5. Compare the values of rectangle1 and rectangle2.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bounds for PrintPreviewControl and its accessible object don't match" (#9175)

Issues.Title: Exception pops up when executing ImageList.ImageCollection.SetKeyName(Int32 index, String name)
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-preview.5.23274.2

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it doesn't reproduced in .Net 7.0.

### Issue description

Exception pops up when executing ImageList.ImageCollection.SetKeyName(Int32 index, String name), it may be caused by PR: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9073

**Failed log:**

System.IndexOutOfRangeException
  HResult=0x80131508
  Message=Index was outside the bounds of the array.
  Source=System.Windows.Forms
  StackTrace:
   at System.Windows.Forms.ImageList.ImageCollection.SetKeyName(Int32 index, String name)
   at WinFormsApp6.Form1.InitializeComponent() in C:\Users\xxx\source\repos\WinFormsApp6\WinFormsApp6\Form1.Designer.cs:line 40
   at WinFormsApp6.Form1..ctor() in C:\Users\xxx\source\repos\WinFormsApp6\WinFormsApp6\Form1.cs:line 7
   at WinFormsApp6.Program.Main() in C:\Users\xxx\source\repos\WinFormsApp6\WinFormsApp6\Program.cs:line 14


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a .NET Core 8.0 application with ImageList Control
2. Open ImageList smart tag and click "Choose images"
3. Add some image
4. Build and run

![Screenshot 2023-05-25 022221](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/8ec09e63-d2e1-4c2f-9911-f64f4477a247)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/e1c78781-3033-4730-a5c9-404917ec26f7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Exception pops up when executing ImageList.ImageCollection.SetKeyName(Int32 index, String name)" (#9174)

Issues.Title: Toolstripmenuitem under menubar cannot clearly distinguish checkstate is checked or unchecked
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-preview.5.23274.2

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, this issue also repro in .NET7.0 & .NET 6.0 & .NET 5.0 & .NET 3.1.

### Issue description

Toolstripmenuitem under menubar cannot clearly distinguish checkstate is checked or unchecked

Toolstripbutton under menubar can learly distinguish checkstate is checked or unchecked, checked state has rectangle box.
![toolstripmenuitem](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/4d59b139-7c7d-406f-9356-3e350167ebc5)

Toolstripmenuitem under menu can clearly distinguish checkstate is checked or unchecked, checked state has check symbol.
![Screenshot 2023-05-25 081546](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/ed0dc811-4660-4297-9a33-4ba381df9cb4)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .net core application with MenuStrip control
2. Add 2 menuitem under menubar
3. Change toolstripmenuitem2 checkstate property is checked
4. Build and run application
5. Observe toolstripmenuitem2

or use this sample application:
[test.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11562500/test.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Toolstripmenuitem under menubar cannot clearly distinguish checkstate is checked or unchecked" (#9173)

Issues.Title: DataGridViewDesigner is missing in System.Windows.Forms.Design namespace (.NET 6/7)
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7 windows
.NET 6 windows

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

it does not look it was ever ported to .NET Core

### Issue description

We use .NET System.Windows.Forms.Design services for the run-time implementation of the Form designer functionality.
Under .NET Framework 4.6+ we could invoke DataGridView designer by clicking on the action item to add columns, etc.
It seems that this class completely missing in .NET 6/7

### Steps to reproduce

We have our demo projects here:
https://github.com/alternetsoft/alternet-studio-examples
The issue can be reproduced with FormDesigner demo, it can not load designer at all and displays DataGridView as a component.
If we use ControlDesigner instead of DataGridViewDesigner, it works fine, but does not display additional action items.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DataGridViewDesigner is missing in System.Windows.Forms.Design namespace (.NET 6/7)" (#9165)

Issues.Title: Make AccessibleObject owner references weak references
Issues.Body:
This is to help ensure that the owner references can be be collected if the AccessibleObject CCW is the only thing still alive. We fall back onto "default" behavior if the related component is gone.

Added an internal IAccessibleOwner interface to allow attaching behavior to different AccessibleObject hierarchies. Changed most usages to TryGetOwnerAs to make it easier to audit Owner access.

Issues.Title: Fix rooting of ReflectParent
Issues.Body:
Control.ReflectParent holds onto the parent control so it can know if it needs to be recreated when the parent is recreated. Making this a WeakReference to allow the Parent to be collected if it isn't going to be reused.

While this fixes the rooting via ReflectParent, in testing the parent was still rooted by its ControlAccessibleObject.Owner reference's. It's COM callable wrapper was still ref counted. I don't see that we're doing anything obviously wrong with the interop there, but in any case it's sort of senseless to retain a ref to an unused Control. I'm exploring making the owner a WeakReference as well, but it is a pretty big change as we stash the handle in a number of derived classes.

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner does not handle mouse messages on adorner window such as resizing
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET Core 7

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Works fine for .NET 6

### Issue description

We use .NET System.Windows.Forms.Design services for the run-time implementation of the Form designer functionality.
Form designer works fine in .Net core 6 (and .net 4.62), allowing placing and resizing controls on the design surface. However, resizing does not work with .net 7.



### Steps to reproduce

It would be hard to give a reproducible scenario, but by tracing the source code, we've found the following:

.NET 6
BehaviorService.cs
...
private bool ProcessMouseMessage(IntPtr hWnd, Interop.User32.WM msg, int x, int y)
    Point point = new Point(x, y);
    Interop.User32.MapWindowPoints(IntPtr.Zero, adornerWindow.Handle, ref point, 1U);
    Message message = Message.Create(hWnd, msg, (IntPtr)0, Interop.PARAM.FromLowHigh(p.Y, p.X));

.NET 7

BehaviorService.cs
...
private bool ProcessMouseMessage(IntPtr hWnd, Interop.User32.WM msg, int x, int y)
    Point point = new Point(x, y);
    adornerWindow.PointToClient(p); // should be p =adornerWindow.PointToClient(p);
    Message message = Message.Create(hWnd, msg, (IntPtr)0, Interop.PARAM.FromLowHigh(p.Y, p.X));

adornerWindow.PointToClient internally uses MapWindowPoints, but its result is ignored. This is causing sending screen coordinates to the adornerWindow and clearing _hitTestedGlyph field, which results in adorners not behaving as they should.
The same applies to the designer action glyph (displayed at the top right corner of the selected control) - it does nothing on our tests.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner does not handle mouse messages on adorner window such as resizing " (#9160)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the progress of the VScrollbar/HScrollbar when updating it
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 8.0 SDK build: 8.0.100-preview.5.23268.13

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

When using keyboard to update the progress of the VScrollbar/HScrollbar controls, Narrator cannot announce the progress updating

.Net 8.0:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/e472cdb7-487e-4ea2-85b7-90487058670b)
![ScrollbarProgress](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/915e9726-23d9-4bba-a659-f735a552467e)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/bf38e7d2-95eb-471c-883a-e88bca62831c)


### Steps to reproduce

Repro steps:
1. Create a Winforms .net core application with VScrollbar/HScrollbar
2. Build and run application
3. Launch Narrator, and use keyboard to focus on VScrollbar/HScrollbar control to update its progress 

or use this sample application:
[WinFormsApp19.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11529647/WinFormsApp19.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the progress of the VScrollbar/HScrollbar when updating it" (#9158)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of CheckBox correctly
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 8.0 SDK build: 8.0.100-preview.5.23268.13

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it is a regression issue, cannot repro in .Net Core 3.1, and repro in .Net 5, 6, 7 versions

### Issue description

When set CheckBox's CheckState to **Indeterminate**, Narrator cannot announce that state is **Indeterminate**, but "Checked".

**.Net 8.0:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/2352ea55-16d7-48c5-bad1-8b25df310ee9)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/45ed5dbb-95c6-400f-9a1f-90f83346f1c2)

**.Net Core 3.1:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/b9246b17-0dba-4c65-9e3c-1ca5a656624b)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/08deb3a7-12c5-46e6-807a-370c30ac02cf)

**.Net framework 4.8.1:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/df62153a-eb1a-4d47-a92b-e700c83802d7)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/62d8b750-1ee8-4c6c-88cd-09b248585146)


### Steps to reproduce

**Repro steps:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application with CheckBox
2. Set CheckBox's CheckState to **Indeterminate**
3. Build and run application
4. Launch Narrator to focus on CheckBox

or use this sample application:
[WinFormsApp19.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11528028/WinFormsApp19.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of CheckBox correctly " (#9157)

Issues.Title: TypeLoadException on System.Windows.Forms.Control.SetAcceptDrops in DotNet 8 Preview 4 when Trimming
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0.100-preview.4.23260.5

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No (Not applicable)

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it works fine in DotNet 7.

### Issue description

During runtime, after I publish my app as a self-contained, trimmed (does not matter the mode) executable, I get the following error even before any form is shown:

```
System.TypeLoadException
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.SetAcceptDrops(Boolean)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnHandleCreated(EventArgs)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.WmCreate(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl.WndProc(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.WndProc(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Application.ParkingWindow.WndProc(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.ControlNativeWindow.OnMessage(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.ControlNativeWindow.WndProc(Message&)
   at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.Callback(HWND, WM, WPARAM, LPARAM)
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Mae a simple WinForms app with a User Control in it on the main form.
2. Publish with trimming enabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TypeLoadException on System.Windows.Forms.Control.SetAcceptDrops in DotNet 8 Preview 4 when Trimming" (#9155)

Issues.Title: VB FileLogTraceListerner creates Application.UserAppDataPath whether it's needed or not
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

All versions

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

no

### Issue description

Since a reference to Application.UserAppDataPath creates its directory if needed, the initialization of _CustomLocation in FileLogTraceListener also does so, even if that is not the intended destination for the log file(s).  It would be better to move that initialization to the Get clause of the CustomLocation property.

### Steps to reproduce

Any creation of a FileLogTraceListener object in Visual Basic creates the directory.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "VB FileLogTraceListerner creates Application.UserAppDataPath whether it's needed or not" (#9154)

Issues.Title: F1 (help) not working on control's properties
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2022
Version 17.6.0
VisualStudio.17.Release/17.6.0+33712.159
Microsoft .NET Framework
Version 4.8.09032

### .NET version

6.0, 7.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Yes in .Net framework designer

### Issue description

When you press F1 on any property in designer's propertygrid you must be redirected to appropriate msdn page. But currently designer trying to use proxy object for this case. For example `Form.Text` property:
Expexted
`https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.form.text?f1url=%3FappId%3DDev16IDEF1%26l%3DEN-US%26k%3Dk(System.Windows.Forms.Form.Text)%3Bk(System.Windows.Forms.Form)%3Bk(VS.Properties)%26rd%3Dtrue&view=windowsdesktop-7.0`

Current 
```https://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev16.query?appId=Dev16IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k(Microsoft.DotNet.DesignTools.Client.Proxies.ControlProxy`1 .... very very long string``` and as result:

> The resource you are looking for has been removed, had its name changed, or is temporarily unavailable.

This is also a problem for custom control designers. I've asked same question [here](https://github.com/microsoft/winforms-designer-extensibility/issues/4#issuecomment-1509875779), but never got answered :(
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "F1 (help) not working on control's properties" (#9151)
